tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is for the director of music to use in worship."
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.

tn.ref: How long, Yahweh, will you keep forgetting about me?
tn.text: This question is asked to get the reader's attention and to add emphasis. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "Yahweh, it seems that you have forgotten about me!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

The words "your face" represent God's whole being. This rhetorical question is asked to add emphasis. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "It seems like you are hiding from me!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: How long will my enemy triumph over me?
tn.text: This rhetorical question is asked to add emphasis. It can be translated as a statement. AT: "Surely my enemies will not always defeat me!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Look at me and answer me
tn.text: "Give me your attention and listen to me"
This is a way of asking for strength. AT: "Make me strong again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: or I will sleep in death
tn.text: To "sleep in death" means to die. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: Do not let my enemy say ... so that my enemy may not say
tn.text: "Do not let my enemy say about me ... so that my enemy may not say about me"
"when I fall" or "when they defeat me"

tn.ref: I have trusted in your covenant faithfulness
tn.text: In speaking of Yahweh's "covenant faithfulness," David is trusting that Yahweh will always love him. AT: "I trust that you will faithfully love me" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: my heart rejoices in your salvation
tn.text: Here "my heart" represents the whole person. AT: "I will rejoice because you have rescued me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
